TI: Functional clustering algorithm for the analysis of dynamic network data.
AB: We formulate a technique for the detection of functional clusters in discrete event data. The advantage of this algorithm is that no prior knowledge of the number of functional groups is needed, as our procedure progressively combines data traces and derives the optimal clustering cutoff in a simple and intuitive manner through the use of surrogate data sets. In order to demonstrate the power of this algorithm to detect changes in network dynamics and connectivity, we apply it to both simulated neural spike train data and real neural data obtained from the mouse hippocampus during exploration and slow-wave sleep. Using the simulated data, we show that our algorithm performs better than existing methods. In the experimental data, we observe state-dependent clustering patterns consistent with known neurophysiological processes involved in memory consolidation.
AD: Department of Physics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan 48109, USA. sarahfel@umich.edu
TA: Phys Rev E Stat Nonlin Soft Matter Phys
JT: Physical review. E, Statistical, nonlinear, and soft matter physics
SO: Phys Rev E Stat Nonlin Soft Matter Phys. 2009 May;79(5 Pt 2):056104. doi: 10.1103/PhysRevE.79.056104. Epub 2009 May 7.
